\section{Introduction}\label{intro}  {Since the discovery of 
the cosmic acceleration through measurements of the Supernova Type 
Ia Hubble diagram \cite{Riess1998,Perlmutter1999}, a variety of 
cosmological probes have provided compelling evidence that the bulk 
of matter in the universe is in the form of an unknown Dark Energy 
(DE) component. On the one hand, observations of the Cosmic 
Microwave Background anisotropies have unconfutably shown that the 
Universe is spatially flat (e.g. Planck's measurements constrain the 
curvature parameter to $|\Omega_K| \lesssim 0.005$ \cite
{Planck_Cosmo}). On the other hand, measurements of the large scale 
distribution of galaxies indicate that matter in cosmic structures 
is in an invisible Dark Matter (DM) form which only accounts for 
about $30\%$ (with errors hardly exceeding the $2\%$ level) of the 
total matter/energy budget of the Universe (see e.g. \cite
{Survey_BAO}). Therefore, indipendently of direct tests of the 
cosmic expansion, a new dark phenomenon filling this gap must be at 
work.}

 {A cosmological constant ($\Lambda$) in Einstein's equations 
of General Relativity (GR) could provide the missing link. In fact, 
this term is equivalent to a negative pressure fluid characterized 
by an equation of state $w=-1$ which causes the cosmic expansion to 
accelerate when $\Lambda$ becomes the dominant energy component in 
the Universe. Moreover, such a constant could account for the energy 
contribution of quantum vacuum fluctuations to the cosmic curvature. 
It is therefore remarkable that this simple scenario, in combination 
with the Cold Dark Matter (CDM) paradigm, so called $\Lambda$CDM 
model, has been able, over the past two decades, to reproduce all 
cosmological observations above galactic scales.}

 {However, the expected value of the vacuum energy density 
according to quantum field theory, can be reconciled with the 
cosmologically inferred value of $\Lambda$, only at the expences of 
an extreme fine tuning.}

Alternative ideas have then been put forward; they range from DE being a
self--interacting scalar field
\cite{RatraPeebles1988,Wetterich1988,Ellis1989,CaldwellSteinhard1999},
possibly interacting also with DM -- to DE being no {\it substance},
but a manifestation of the violation of General Relativity on cosmic
scales (for a comprensive review see, e.g. \cite{Clifton2012}).

Despite the variety of scenarios none of the theoretical DE models
thus far proposed provides a compelling explanation of the cosmic
acceleration. This is essentially due to the lack of new fundamental
principles that may guide the theoretical model building. In the
absence of such a guidance, observational searches have turned toward
more phenomenological approaches that aim to test the dynamical nature
of dark energy directly from data.

The simplest approach consists in constraining a constant equation of
state parameter $w$. Planck data in combination with other
cosmological probes give $-1.10 < w < -0.94$ at $1\sigma$
\cite{Planck_Cosmo}. However, a constant equation of state 
is

a too simplistic parametrization that does not

allow us to compare a $\Lambda$CDM cosmology with the

predictions of dynamical models of DE such as quintessence: a

model suggesting that DE is a

self-interacting scalar field with tracker potential
(e.g. \cite{RatraPeebles1988,CaldwellSteinhard1999}). Moreover, even
though no such models exhibit a greater likelihood, assuming a simple
constant equation of state may bias the result of the model parameter
inference, especially if DE is highly dynamical, as originally pointed
out in \cite{Wasserman2002}.


In the attempt to

account for time variation in DE equation of state, it

was suggested  \cite{Chevalier2000,Linder2003}

to use a first order expansion in the scale factor of the form
$w(a)=w_0+(1-a)w_a$. 
We will refer to this as the CPL parametrization. As shown in
\cite{Bassett2004}, the use of such simple expansion and alike is not
exempt of pitfalls either. Furthermore, this parametrization is
limited to reproducing predictions of DE models with slowly varying
equation of states, whereas more general time evolutions may require
non-perturbative parametrizations as earlier suggested in
\cite{Corasaniti2002}.

Despite such limitations, this two-parameter model of DE significantly
widens the range of models

to be compared with

data. For instance, under the most conservative hypotheses, the
constraints on $w_0$ appear to widen compared to the constant equation
of state case, in particular $-1.25 < w_0 <-0.65$ at $1\sigma$. This
is because of degeneracies

in

the extended DE parameter space. 

In this connection, Fig.~28 of \cite{Planck_Cosmo}, that we reproduce
here in Fig.~\ref{fig:planckfig}, is quite significant, namely for
what concerns the agreement of CFHTLensS \footnote{Canada France Haway
  Telescope Lensing Survey} weak lensing data \cite{Erbenetal} with
other datasets. If the latter are disregarded, $w_0$--$w_a$
constraints are however reasonably stringent, being represented by the
small blue ellipses. In particular, the cosmological constant case
lays within the $1\sigma$ contour. On the contrary, there is
  tension with weak lensing data: if they are taken into account, the
marginalized $1$ and $2\sigma$ limits in the $w_0$-$w_a$ plane spread
over a large region of the parameter space where the CPL
parametrization, as a first order expansion in the scale factor,
breaks down (being $|w_a|\approx 1$).























Nevertheless, there is hope that lensing data  and, more generally, the constraints on dark energy
    parameters may significanly improve in the future.
In fact, while CMB measurements have almost reached cosmic variance
limited errors (although improvements in the polarization spectra are
still possible), progress can be made thanks to the upcoming
generation of galaxy surveys such as
LSST\footnote{http://www.lsst.org/lsst/} and the {\sc Euclid}
experiment \cite{laureijs}. They are expected to measure the power
spectrum of matter density fluctuations, $P(k)$, to per-cent level
accuracy across a wide range of scales and redshifts. Let us remark
that analysing of these data is quite challenging, since an unbiased
statistical parameter inference will then require model predictions to
be also accurate to one percent or more.

On the very large scales the matter power spectrum can be computed to
the desired level of accuracy using the perturbation theory. However,
to per-cent level even at the scale of BAO the effects of
non-linearities in the dynamics of the late-time of clustering of
matter cannot be neglected (see e.g. \cite{Rasera2014}), thus
presumably requiring beyond perturbation theory calculations.


At {larger} $k$ values, only N-body simulation results {can provide
  model predictions}.  This would however demand a significant effort
to overcome ambiguities due to sample variance, dependence on the box
size and long-wavelength mode contributions, resolution and dynamical
range across the entire model parameter space. In turn, this excludes
that the required N-body simulations may be part of an ``on line''
algorithm evaluating {a} model likelihood. Accordingly, future galaxy
survey data analyses require reliable and readily available spectral
predictions from N--body siimulations. Henceforth, a number of methods
have been developped to provide estimates of the non-linear power
spectrum either through simulation emulators or semi-analytical
models. The latter is the case of the Peacock-Dodds formula
\cite{Peacock1996} based on the halo model, whose expressions then
evolved into Halofit \cite{Smith2003}. This has been greatly improved
and further extended to include DE models with constant equation of
state \cite{Takahashi2012}. It has also been implemented in the CAMB
code \cite{Lewis2000} while, recently, the authors of \cite{Mead2015}
have included prescriptions to account for the effect of baryons.

Emulators, on the other hand, merely rely on N-body simulation suites
performed over a grid of models that allow one to estimate the
non-linear matter power spectrum for a given set of cosmological model
parameters. This is the case of two public available emulators Coyote
\cite{Heitmann2014} and PkANN \cite{Agarwal2014}.

The Coyote emulator is based on a suite of simulations that provide
estimates of the non-linear power spectrum to $1\%$ accuracy in the
redshift range $0\le z \le 1$ and up to $k \simeq 2\, h\, $Mpc$^{-1}$
in the following interval of model parameters: constant equation of
state $-1.3 \le w \le -0.7$, mean baryon density
$0.0215\le\omega_b=\Omega_bh^2\le 0.0235$, mean matter density
$0.120\le\omega_m=\Omega_mh^2\le 0.155$, scalar spectral index
$0.85\le n_s\le 1.05$ and normalization amplitude $0.6 \le\sigma_8\le
0.9$. For a given value of $w$ and $\omega_m$ the reduced Hubble
constant $h$ is set such as to reproduce the location of the CMB peaks
in the temperature anisotropy power spectrum.

 {This last step outlines that, within the restricted range of values
   ($h\sim0.7$) now allowed by observations, the matter power spectrum
   exhibit a minor dependence on the Hubble parameter, a point which
   is directly connected with the model equivalence criterion we shall
   describe next. In fact, the very reason making redundant a full
   mapping of the $h$ dependence of the matter power spectra has been
   exploited by \cite{Casarini2009} (see also
   \cite{Casarini2010a,Casarini2010b}) to extend to any $z$ the
   spectral model equivalente at $z=0$ introduced by
   \cite{Francis2007}.}

 {As a matter of fact, \cite{Francis2007} have noticed that two
   cosmologies exhibit almost identical spectra in a large $k$
   interval at $z=0$, when they share the same density parameters
   $\Omega_{m,c,d}$ (for matter, CDM, DE), the value of $H_0$, the
   root mean square amplitude of density fluctuations on the $8\,
   h^{-1}$Mpc scale $\sigma_8$, and the comoving distance to the Last
   Scattering Surface $d_{LSS}$. They applied this criterion to a
   number of CPL models with assigned $w_0$--$w_a$ values to find the
   corresponding constant $w$ model expected to exhibit the same
   spectrum at $z=0$, and showed that their spectra differ by no more
   than $0.5\,\%$. However, we will show that the use of this spectra
   equivalence criterion to map models to $z \neq 0$ leads to
   inaccurate results. In contrast, by relaxing the requirements in
   accordance with \cite{Casarini2009,Casarini2010a,Casarini2010b}, we
   can establish a spectral equivalence criterion valid at any $z$ for
   which discrepancies between the non-linear power spectra never
   exceed $\sim 0.5\%$ over a large range of scales. Hence, such a
   criterion provides an efficient method to extend spectral
   predictions for models with constant state parameter, at any $z$,
   to the CPL model parameter space.}

An extension of the Coyote emulator to CPL models has been recently
described in \cite{Heitmann2015}\footnote{To date the emulator is not
  publicly available.}. This makes use of a larger set of N-body
simulations covering the $w_0$-$w_a$ parameter space. Here, we show
that spectra of CPL models can be directly inferred 

from those with constant equation of state, with an accuracy well
  below 1$\, \%$. In this paper, therefore, we discuss which CPL
model spectra can be obtained through the Coyote emulator, taking into
account the range of constant $w$ models it is able to emulate. Quite
remarkably we find that the allowed range fully covers the small
2--$\sigma$ ellipse in Fig.~1 \cite{Planck_Cosmo}, for which CFHTLenS
data are disregarded. In addition, we provide a routine that yield a
reliable extension to CPL models of the algorithm used to estimate the
non-linear power spectra in the public code CAMB.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we will review the
mapping rule between $w_0-w_a$ model parameters and $w_{eq}$ \cite
{Casarini2009}, providing explicit algorithms to implement it. In
Section 3 we test the validity of the spectral equivalence using
results from a set of N-body simulations. In Section 4 we discuss the
physical origin of the spectral equivalence and compare results from
different model mapping criteria. Section 5 is then devoted to a
precise determination of CPL models to which the Coyote emulator can
be extended.


\section{Non-Linear Matter Power Spectrum and Model Equivalence}

\subsection{Target and Auxiliary Models}
The imprint of DE on the non-linear regime of cosmic structure
formation has been investigated in a wide range of numerical studies.
They clearly showed that a signature of DE state equation is present
on the mass power spectrum \cite
{Ma1999,McDonald2006,Ma2007,Casarini2009,Alimi2010,Jenning2010}, the
halo mass function \cite{Bode2001,Klypin2003,Courtin2011} as well as
the density profile of DM halos \cite
{Klypin2003,Dolag2004,Deboni2013}. On these different observables the
effects of DE correlate with the linear growth history of the model,
as given by linear growth factor $D(a)$. This is direct consequence of
the fact that, on scales larger than the stable clustering regime, the
non-linear growth does not erase the imprint of the linear fluctuation
growth \cite{Ma2007}. As DE alters the linear growth through its
effects on the late time cosmic expansion its imprint is also left on
the non-linear clustering of matter.  Hence, DE models that exibit
very different linear growth histories (i.e. different $D(a)$) will
leave larger signatures in the non-linear clustering regime and
viceversa. This is not surprising as, in an expanding background, the
linear growth factor defines a time-variable we can use to rewrite the
equations of motion of a gravitating system of collisionless
particles, in a form almost independent from the underlying cosmology
\cite{Nusser1998}.

These arguments provide the physical basis for defining procedures
aimed to estimate the non-linear spectra of a given cosmology from
N-body simulations of an equivalent model, which predicts a similar
linear growth history. These procedures should accurately estimate
matter power spectra in a wavenumber interval relevant to future
measurements and where baryonic physics does not yet require
significant corrections.

Here, we consider matter power spectra in the range 
$0.1\lesssim k/(h\, \textrm{Mpc}^{-1})\lesssim 1.5$. The top limit is
set by baryon physics being no longer negligible. The bottom limit is
set by technical reasons: testing spectral equivalence would there
require large volume N-body simulations for which sample variance and
systematic errors can hardly match a $1\%$ accuracy level.

Hereafter, we will detail the method introduced in \cite
{Casarini2009} to map DE models with constant equation of state and 
those parametrized by the CPL formula so that they share the same 
non-linear power spectrum to great accuracy over the scales and 
redshifts of interest. As already mentioned in Section~\ref{intro} 
this procedure generalizes to all redshift the methodology described 
in \cite{Francis2007}.

To clarify the terminology we refer to a DE model with CPL
parametrization and specified by the value of $w_0$ and $w_a$ as the
\textit{target} model ${\cal M}$, while we refer to a DE model with
constant equation of state $w_{eq}$ with known non-linear power
spectrum at redshift $z$ as the \textit{auxiliary} model ${\cal
  M}_{eq}$  for such redshift. The other cosmological parameters
such as the matter  (baryon, CDM) density  parameters
$\Omega_m$  ($\Omega_b,~\Omega_c$), the radiation density
$\Omega_r$, the scalar spectral index $n_s$ and the reduced Hubble
parameter $h$ are kept fixed in both models  at $z=0$.

Henceforth, at $z \neq 0$, ${\cal M}$ and ${\cal M}_{eq}$ will share
the values of the reduced density parameters $\omega_{m,b,c} =
\Omega_{m,b,c} h^2$, but have different $h(z)$ values. In spite of
such weakening of the criterion stated by \cite{Francis2007} for
$z=0$, target and auxiliary models do exibit almost identical
spectra.

Suppose that for a given set of parameters specifying model ${\cal 
M}$ we want to determine the value of $w_{eq}$ and the present 
normalization amplitude of the power spectrum $\sigma_{8,eq}$ in 
model ${\cal M}_{eq}$, such that both models have the same 
non-linear power spectra at redshift $z$. As shown in \cite
{Casarini2009} this requires imposing two conditions. First, by 
demanding that ${\cal M}$ and ${\cal M}_{eq}$ have the same distance 
to the last scattering surface one can infer the value of $w_{eq}$ 
by numerically solving the equation:

  by the non-linear dynamics of baryons. In this way we could reach a
  deeper physical understanding to assess whether residual
  cosmological signatures are present on stable clustering scales.}



\section{CPL parameter range of the Coyote emulator}
The Coyote emulator provides non-linear power spectra for DE models
with constant equation of state. Thus, we can use the spectral model
equivalence described in the previous Section to extend the
predictions to the CPL parameter space. Here, we determine the range
of values of $w_0$ and $w_a$ that for a given value of $\sigma_8$ and
at a given redshift have an auxiliary model with values of $w_{eq}$
and $\sigma_{8,eq}$ in the range covered by the Coyote emulator.

Hereafter, we set $h=0.70$, $\omega_b=0.048$, $\Omega_m=0.7$ and
$n_s=0.966$ which are well within the range probed by the Coyote
suite.

higher redshift the availability of auxiliary models depends on

\section{Conclusions}
In this work we have first revisited the equivalence between
non-linear matter power spectra of DE models with constant equation of
state (auxiliary models) and those with a time varying one
parametrized by the CPL formula (target models) originally proposed in
\cite{Casarini2009}.

By using a series of N-body simulations runs we have shown that such
equivalence maps the non-linear power spectra of these two class of
models with discrepancies below sub-percent level in the range of
modes $0.1<k<1.5$ and at redshifts $0 \leq z \leq 3$.

The remarkable precision of this equivalence points to a degeneracy of
the imprint of DE on the non-linear matter power power spectrum. This
is because the non-linear regime of gravitational collapse does not
erase information on the past linear growth, quite the opposite it
carries a signature of it. Since DE models alter the linear growth of
matter density perturbations through the effects on the late time
cosmic expansion, this lead to signatures of DE on the non-linear
regime of cosmic structure formation as already pointed out in a vast
literature. Hence, models that exibits similar linear growth histories
also show very similar non-linear power spectra. The conditions for
the spectral equivalence defined by Eqs.~(\ref{firstcond})
and~(\ref{secondcond}) guarantees to maps models with such
properties. 

We have compared the model mapping criterion \cite{Casarini2009} 
with alternative ones and found that it performs better. This result
outlines the key role of comoving distance or conformal time in 
comparing linear (and, henceforth, nonlinear) evolutions.

The essential contribution of this work however concerns a set of 
new algorithms, based on this equivalence criterion and now made 
available. In fact, spectral equivalence allows us to provide an 
improved emulator extending the predictions of the Coyote suite to 
the non-linear matter power spectrum of DE models with CPL 
parametrization. 

We have also shown that the bulk of the CPL parameter space 
(compatible with current cosmological constraints) has auxiliary 
models in the Coyote suite, although high $\sigma_8$ values, 
marginally compatible with available cosmological limits, are just 
on the edge of the extended emulator at $z=1$, if rather high $w_0$ 
values are tentatively compensated by strongly negative $w_a$. Let 
us also remind that the Coyote emulator, both in the original and 
our extended versions, works up to $z=1$ only.

On the contrary, the extended Halofit expressions also included in 
the CAMB program, formally work at any $z$ and $\sigma_8$. 
Accordingly, beside a code that can be used individually or joined 
with Coyote Emulator, we developed a module, which can be inserted 
in the CAMB package, and allows one to obtain non linear power 
spectrua for any $w_0$--$w_a$, in agreement with our equivalence 
criterion. This routine, e.g., can be immediately used in likelihood 
analyses of non-linear matter power spectrum measurements.
